basics.name: Muhammad Bilal Azam
basics.label: Graduate Research Assistant | PhD Candidate in Physics
basics.summary: PhD candidate in Physics at Illinois Institute of Technology and Graduate Research Assistant at Argonne National Laboratory. Member of the DUNE Collaboration, specializing in AI/ML-based neutrino event reconstruction, simulation, and analysis for the DUNE Near Detector Prototype (2×2).

work.name: Argonne National Laboratory
work.summary: Contributing to detector development and data analysis for the DUNE experiment, with focus on calibration system design, generator validation, and AI-driven event reconstruction on high-performance computing systems.

work.name: Lahore University of Management Sciences (LUMS)
work.summary: Worked on dark energy models in curved spacetime under causal set theory.

work.name: FAST National University of Computer and Emerging Sciences
work.summary: Delivered undergraduate lectures in applied physics and electronics.

work.name: University of Sahiwal
work.summary: Taught advanced physics courses including Relativity, Quantum Physics, and Electromagnetic Theory.

education.summary: PhD in Experimental High Energy Physics under Prof. Dr. Zelimir Djurcic; research focuses on AI/ML-based neutrino reconstruction and DUNE 2×2 data analysis.
Master’s thesis on dark energy in causal set theory, addressing the fine-tuning problem via unimodular gravity.
Bachelor’s and Master’s studies emphasizing theoretical and experimental physics.
